title: Is the pasty really Cornish?
intro: Rob and Neil discuss the origins of the Cornish pasty. This traditional tasty snack is popular around the world but does it have to be made in this region of England to make it a genuine Cornish pasty and are there other versions of it that are made elsewhere?
this_week_question: What is the traditional filling in an authentic Cornish pasty? Is it:
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: traditional dishes made from a silver-coloured metal called pewter
people who do physical work, especially outdoors
the time of year when crops like wheat or barley are cut and collected from the fields
digging up materials such as coal, diamonds or metals like gold and tin from the ground
done again in exactly the same way
making you remember a particular person, place or thing

transcript.text: Fancy a game of ‘food connections’, Rob? I’ll name a place and you say the first food that comes to mind. Ready?

transcript.author: Rob

transcript.text: But what exactly is a pasty, Neil? Somewhere between a pie and a sandwich, right? A piece of pastry which is turned over and crimped along the side to make two corners…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: … and filled with different ingredients - which brings me to my quiz question for today, Rob. What is the traditional filling in an authentic Cornish pasty? Is it:

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, chorizo is Spanish isn’t it? And avocado with brie doesn’t sound traditionally Cornish, so I’ll say b) beef, potato and turnip.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, Rob. We’ll find out later if you were right. What’s for sure is that the Cornish pasty has had a long history as BBC Radio 4’s The Food Programme discovered. transcript.text: There’s a lovely bit here where he’s describing what a housewife in Hertfordshire does and he’s talking about her way to make pork pies and pork pasties: pies may be made and baked either raised in paste earthen pans or in pewter dishes or in the shape of a turnover, two-cornered pasties. transcript.text: The earliest pasties were made in pewter dishes – a traditional cooking plate made of a silver-coloured metal called ‘pewter’.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And they were eaten by agricultural labourers – workers doing physical farm work during harvest time – the weeks in autumn when crops like wheat are cut and collected from the fields.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But it wasn’t only farmers and labourers who ate pasties. As well as its farms and fishing, Cornwall was famous for tin mines, as Ruth Huxley of the Cornish Pasty Association explains:

transcript.author: Ruth Huxley, Cornish Pasty Association
transcript.text: Pasties would have been eaten by lots of people who went to work but it just worked perfectly down mines, and Cornwall became the world capital of mining. transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Pasties were eaten by hungry workers involved in the mining industry - digging up materials such as coal or metals like gold, or in Cornwall tin, from the ground.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So far we’ve been talking about Cornwall. But you said the Cornish pasty has spread around the world, Neil. How did that happen?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that’s connected to the tin miners we just talked about. Here’s Polly Russell again:

transcript.author: Polly Russell, Public Life Curator, British Library
transcript.text: This is r eplicated , not just in Mexico but with migrants moving to America, to Minnesota, to Canada, to Australia. So anyone who travels to many of those places now will see foods which are incredibly reminiscent and familiar and just like Cornish pasties.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In the 19th century, many Cornish tin miners emigrated, moving abroad to start a better life. Their pasty recipes were replicated – or copied exactly, in the new places where they landed, from America to Australia.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And that’s why in many places around the world you can find food which is reminiscent of pasties – meaning it reminds you of something similar, in this case the original Cornish pasty… with its traditional filling of… what’s was your quiz question again, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Ah, yes. I asked you what the traditional Cornish pasty filling was? You said…

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I said b) beef, potato and turnip.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And you were right! ‘Keslowena’, Rob – that’s Cornish for ‘congratulations’!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: ‘Heb grev’, Neil – that’s ‘no problem’!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In fact those other fillings – chorizo, avocado and brie - really did feature in pasties entered for this year’s Annual World Pasty Championships, held in Cornwall every spring. Other pasty-inspired ideas include Argentinian chimichurri empanadas and spicy Jamaican patties.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: So the pasty is still going strong, both in Cornwall and around the world.

transcript.author: Neil

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Later, when these miners emigrated to new lands, pasties were replicated – cooked again in the same way.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: In fact Cornish miners moved to so many new countries that today, almost every corner of the world has food reminiscent of – or reminding you of, the original Cornish pasty.
